_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Genencor International Inc., Cedar Rapids
Risk Management Plan


Introduction to Facility & Regulated Substance

Genencor International, Inc. (?GCOR?) is an industrial biotechnology facility that manufactures industrial enzymes.  The facility is located on the southwest side of Cedar Rapids at the intersection of 41st Avenue Drive and C Street Southwest.  This ISO 9000:2000 certified facility employs 81 people and operates under a team-based organizational structure.  

In March of 1999, Genencor initiated an effort to enhance the existing management system for the site.  This effort was guided by sustainable development principles, and incorporated equity, environmental and economic drivers into the site?s management system.  We feel that this ?people/planet/profit? approach to our everyday business is a sound basis for the pursuit of long-term business viability while taking responsibility for improving the environmental, social, and economic conditions resulting from our activities.  Site goals and ongoing initiatives are tracked via yearly measures, which are issued through GCOR?s annual Sustainability Report.  Genencor?s latest sustainability report can be found at www.genencor.com.

The site manufactures enzymes through a fermentation-based process.  Enzymes are chemicals comprised of large proteins, and have been used in the food and detergent manufacturing industries for many years.  The site?s enzyme products are available in liquid or granular form.  The facility operates a continuous 24-hour-per-day process and has on-shift Maintenance and Laboratory support.  Staff support includes site Management, Environmental Health & Safety, Engineering, Purchasing, Finance, and Systems personnel.

Ammonium hydroxide is the regulated substance under EPA Risk Management criteria.  The enzyme manufacturing process requires the use of ammonium hydroxide at 29.9% concentration.  Average on-site storage of ammonium hydroxide solution is approximately 37,

000 liters, equal to 21,887 pounds of ammonia content.  The ammonium hydroxide storage and delivery system is the covered process for the site?s Risk Management efforts and is divided into the following sections or ?nodes? for the purpose of this program:
?    Truck Unloading (includes delivery truck and suction-side of unloading pump)
?    Truck Unloading Pump (includes pump and discharge piping to storage tank)
?    Ammonium Hydroxide Storage Tank & Vent Line (49,000 liters tank capacity)
?    Delivery Pumps (includes delivery pumps and piping)
?    Process Feed and Recirculation Piping
?    Fermentation Vessels
?    Facility (includes entire plant for considering external events such as weather)


Chemical Safety

GCOR?s overall approach to chemical safety is comprehensive.  Systems are engineered with safety and environmental aspects in mind, with input from all affected areas of the plant prior to construction or use.  The goal is to provide a safe workplace while minimizing any environmental impacts.  Release prevention methods are implemented where possible, including computer controls, automation, containment of all outdoor tanks; inside sump areas; and on-site air-scrubbing and neutralization capabilities.

The site?s management team is committed to the implementation of site environmental health & safety programs and supports the following:
The environmental health & safety budget is established to provide:
?    Appropriate and adequate personal protective equipment
?    Appropriate post-offer and annual medical examinations
?    Training
?    Air monitoring equipment and analysis
?    Hazardous waste pick-up for a conditionally-exempt small quantity hazardous waste generator
?    Emergency Response Team equipment and supplies

A site Safety Committee is in place to foster the plant?s overall safety performance.  The committee?s activities are as follows:
Charter:
The charter of the Safety Committee is to be proactive in developing policy for the overall safety of the plant.  The Strategy Team

will set the policy.
Mission Statement:
The mission of the Safety Committee is to promote a safe work environment by leading the way in demonstrating safety is everyone?s responsibility, and individual follow-through on issues is expected. This team is not the safety police.
2004 Goals:
Three plant walk-arounds conducted per year.
Phase 1:  The ratio of the number of Safety Alerts (SA?s) identified by the Safety Committee (SC) versus the Plant will inverse over time.  For example, if SC identifies 100 SA?s in 2004 and the Plant finds 10 SA?s, by 2005 the numbers should be reversed.
Phase 2:  Total number of Safety Alerts will drop over time to some number.  This reflects the proactive safety response by everyone in the plant

The GCOR corporate sustainability vision and expectations lends guidance to site efforts.
Genencor International Sustainability Policy:
Using our expertise in modern biotechnology, Genencor seeks to become a leader in sustainability. We will strive to emulate nature?s elegance ? respecting the interrelationships of living organisms and making the most of the resources we use.  Through innovation and collaboration we will protect the environment, promote the well being of our employees and the world community.  

In the spirit of this intent, we will organize our work activities to improve continually in reducing the impact we have on the environment and to promote efficiency and fairness in our activities.  We will meet legal and internal requirements, minimize pollution and preserve resources.  These efforts will be widely communicated to employees as part of core corporate values.  Progress will be monitored and communicated to our stakeholders, and we will use their input to improve our performance as corporate citizens.  


New employees attend ~14 hours of initial safety training, which includes chemical awareness training as well as various OSHA and EPA-required information.  Job-duty training is ongoing for each employee and occurs with

co-worker trainers utilizing on-the-job observation & partnering, SOP?s, training assessments, and computer-based training programs.  Genencor believes in being proactive in its training endeavors and strives to encourage employees to attend specific training associated with their job duties that go above and beyond the basic job requirements.  

Capital projects deemed necessary for environmental, health & safety reasons are implemented and supported through the capital expenditure process.


Emergency Response 

The site Emergency Action Plan addresses how employees shall respond to emergencies, including hazardous weather; fire; medical; building evacuation; hazardous device threat; utility failure; and hazardous material spills.  All employees are trained in the site Emergency Action Plan as part of the established initial safety training for new employees.

The Emergency Action Plan also introduces the function and responsibilities of the Emergency Response Team (?ERT?).  The ERT members are trained in Industrial Incipient Level Fire Brigade; Technical Level Industrial Chemical Spill Response; First Aid/Adult CPR; Automatic External Defibrillator, and Bloodborne Pathogens.  
Ongoing yearly goals include the following:
?    Complete one drill per crew by designated quarter
?    Complete 3 table-top scenarios
?    Have injury-free responses to all incidents

This group trains yearly as well as conducts drills and tabletop scenarios to prepare for incident handling.  On-site ERT equipment is maintained to support the ERT efforts and includes SCBA?s, Level B chemical resistant suits, chemical absorbent materials, pumps & hoses, and an equipment trailer for timely response to an incident.  

The site Emergency Response Plan for a Hazardous Substance Release is in place to provide ERT guidance for spill operations.  The Incident Command System is the designated management system for emergencies and is included in the plan.  The plan outlines the responsibility of involved per

sonnel during an incident; Discusses the Incident Command System; Gives instruction for securing outside emergency assistance; Addresses internal and external notifications including the media/public; Outlines emergency procedures for general emergency response; Addresses spill control, personal protective equipment & first aid; Covers disposal & decontamination.  All ERT members are trained in the site Emergency Response Plan for a Hazardous Substance Release.  Incident response checklists and incident report forms are used by the GCOR Incident Commander and involved personnel during incidents.  The site Emergency Response Plan for a Hazardous Substance Release is shared with the Cedar Rapids Fire Department and Linn County?s Local Emergency Planning Committee.


General Prevention Measures

Genencor has a number of measures in place for spill prevention.  These include, but are not limited to: An in-depth computer-tracked preventative maintenance program; Standard operating procedures which are updated at least annually; Employee training; Back-up equipment where possible; Computer-monitored level indicators with interlocking systems when process limits are reached; Containment basins.  The facility has 24-hour team-based operations coverage in the facility, including a full-service Maintenance department.  The facility also operates under ISO 9000:2000 certification which ensures among other things, that procedures are updated and used for plant operations in addition to proper handling of all documents.

The presence of an Emergency Response Team (as outlined earlier) ensures that all safety/environmental events are addressed immediately to prevent an escalation of the incident if possible.


Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidents at the Genencor International, Cedar Rapids facility involving the ammonium hydroxide system that resulted in any on-site or off-site effects.


Changes to Improve Safety

A Process Hazard Analysis was conducted for t

he site ammonium hydroxide system in December, 2003.  This was led by an experienced outside consultant and completed by a team with members representing Logistics (process); Fermentation/Media Prep (process); Maintenance; Engineering; Environmental Health & Safety; and site Management.  Eight recommendations for improvement were generated from the Process Hazard Analysis.  All action items are complete.
